images.caption: Figure 1:Feed-forward 3DGS models,e.g., DepthSplat[9], rely on unprojected depth to form 3D Gaussians. The inherent discontinuities of depth near object boundaries often propagate into distorted 3D point clouds (top left) and degraded rendering (bottom left). Our PM-Loss addresses this by using the prior from pointmap, achieving higher-quality geometry (top right) and rendering (bottom right).

Figure 2:Overview of PM-Loss.The process begins by estimating a dense point map of the scene using a pre-trained model. This estimated point map then serves as direct 3D supervision for training a feed-forward 3D Gaussian Splatting model. Crucially, unlike conventional methods relying predominantly on 2D supervision, our approach leverages explicit 3D geometric cues, leading to enhanced 3D shape fidelity.

Figure 3:Qualitative comparisons on DL3DV(top two rows) and RealEstate10K(bottom two rows) under the 2-view extrapolation setting.Adding PM-Loss leads to significant improvements in rendering object boundaries.
Figure 4:Qualitative comparison of unprojected 3D Gaussians on DL3DV dataset.Our method effectively constrains the 3D Gaussians, significantly reducing floating artifacts and noise near border.
Figure 5:Qualitative comparison of unprojected 3D Gaussians on the DTU dataset.
